Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned basic problem solving skills and learned about the foundations of calculus.
Calculus from pre-cal review to basic integrals.
My knowledge of calculus was built upon and strengthened, and I gained a firmer understanding of derivatives and integrals beyond only abstract computations.
I developed a willingness to attend peer tutoring because I needed help during the problem sets. This will serve me well as I continue my college career.
The course provided basic calculus. We learned basic limits, derivation, and integration.
Limits, Integrals, Related Rates, Optimization Problems

In this class I expanded my understanding of calculus. Math 112 is a review of Calculus AB, but it goes deeper into each concept. The skills I developed by taking this course include taking derivatives, integrals, manipulating autonomous differential equations, and finding tricky limits.
Calculus
I learned about limits, derivatives, and integrals.
Advanced my understanding and application skills of calculus topics.
I solidified my knowledge of calc 1.
I gained a deeper understanding of how to do calculus. I learned how to better access outside help and utilize resources for the course.
The lectures were very helpful, and I liked how we were put into small groups to talk with other students about the problems.
It's taught almost entirely by grad students. While my instructor was good, your mileage may vary. The WebAssigns were a bit tedious and a lot less helpful than the weekly problem set.

The method of teaching in this class does not make sense. They do not teach you how to actually apply what you've learned or even how to do it, but rather just lecture about the theorems and proofs that prove the mathematic concepts we learn.

The course did a good job of covering every concept involved in basic calculus, but at times was not particularly engaging. 

The worksheets were a great way of bridging the gap between what was explained in class and the problem sets, which could be difficult to understand and complete without attending the peer tutoring session.
Section times and the lack of a sizable classroom for peer tutoring sessions were weaknesses. The problem sets were also unnecessarily difficult.

A big weakness to the course was Webassign. It is useless and doesn't add anything that the psets and worksheets didn't, but cost me $100 because I already had the textbook. It was also a little disorganized and it was difficult to know what sections/topics I was expected to learn.

Strengths: smaller sections, review sessions, peer tutors
Weaknesses: webassign

The strength of this class is that it challenges your understanding of the concepts from lecture. The lectures go a little deeper than expected into the theory about the basic calculus concepts, but I think it helped me get a better understanding of calculus.
The homework forced you to keep up with the material and practice was provided for exams

Strengths: 
The problem sets and review sessions prepared me well for the exams.  

Weaknesses: 
The derivative quizzes were difficult to complete successfully as there was no partial credit.  Completing math on a computer screen is much harder than completing math on paper (in my opinion).
Weakness the greading was extrememly varied by section.
Make tutors more available and advertised.

The strengths of the course was that there were many outside resources available, including the peer tutors, practice exams, practice tests on the web assign site, textbook help, etc. 

The weaknesses were in how math course are "flipped" at Yale, where the professors expect students to understand the material before class, and they use the class time to practice, not teach. I think that the class time should be used to teach, and there should be more visuals to help teach.
I would recommend this class to another student. The expectations were clearly posted and there weren't any surprises along the way. Also, it was very easy to get outside help.

Yes. If you're in between taking 112 and 115, such as I was, just bite the bullet and take 115. You won't get an "easy" A in this class. Even if you have an understanding of calculus coming in, some of the problems can be tricky.

I would recommend it to those interested in building up their knowledge of math. I learned a lot in the class, even if at times it wasn't as engaging as I would have preferred. I think there is a lot to gain from learning the calculus taught in Math 112, even if someone isn't planning on continuing on to higher level math courses.

I  would recommend this course to students who feel they are not  quite ready for Math 115. The course was fairly easy if you have taken Calculus previously and can serve as a refresher for those who may have forgotten concepts.
I would recommend if needed for a major or QR requirement. Otherwise, there's no need.
Yes, it will provide you with a very strong base for future math classes.
If you can skip 112 and go to 115, then do it. Otherwise, 112 gives you a better foundation of calculus than AP Calculus AB would.
Yes it was very structured
Yes, I would recommend this course to a student if they needed it as a pre-requisite.  I wouldn't recommend this course as an elective, as its work load is high.
Not unless its necessary.
I probably would not recommend it for people who don't need to take it but if you do need to take it it was fine.
I would only recommend this course if the person if required to take math or enjoys math.
